Description: Obesity is a medical condition in which excess body fat has accumulated to the extent that it may have an adverse effect on health. It is a chronic disease that can lead to many other health problems.
Symptoms: increased body weight, difficulty moving, shortness of breath, fatigue, joint pain, sleep apnea, high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, stroke
Treatments: dietary changes, increased physical activity, behavioral therapy, weight-loss medications, bariatric surgery

Description: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a mental disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, recurring thoughts (obsessions) and/or behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat over and over.
Symptoms: obsessions, compulsions, fear of contamination, aggressive impulses, symmetry and orderliness, excessive doubt, hoarding, trichotillomania, skin picking
Treatments: cognitive-behavioral therapy (cbt), exposure and response prevention (erp), medication (ssris)

Description: Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, is a parasitic disease caused by the worm Onchocerca volvulus. It is transmitted to humans through the bites of blackflies.
Symptoms: skin rash, itching, eye lesions, visual impairment
Treatments: ivermectin, doxycycline, surgery (for advanced cases)

Description: Ophthalmia neonatorum is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborn babies. It is usually caused by an infection acquired during delivery from the mother, who may have a sexually transmitted infection.
Symptoms: eye redness, swelling of the eyelids, discharge from the eyes
Treatments: antibiotic eye drops or ointment, preventive measures (e.g. screening and treating pregnant women for stis)

Description: Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. It occurs when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of your bones wears down over time.
Symptoms: joint pain,  neck pain,  knee pain,  hip joint pain,  swelling joints,  painful walking
Treatments: acetaminophen, consult nearest hospital, follow up, salt baths

Description: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease that occurs when the protective cartilage on the ends of bones wears down over time, causing pain, stiffness, and loss of mobility.
Symptoms: pain or stiffness in the joints, especially after periods of inactivity or overuse, swelling or tenderness in the affected joints, a crunching or popping sensation when moving the joint, limited range of motion, bone spurs
Treatments: over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids), prescription medications such as cox-2 inhibitors or corticosteroids, physical therapy or occupational therapy, assistive devices such as braces or canes, lifestyle changes such as losing weight, getting regular exercise, and avoiding activities that exacerbate symptoms

Description: Osteomyelitis is a bone infection that can occur in any bone in the body. It is usually caused by bacteria that enter the bone through a wound or during surgery.
Symptoms: pain and tenderness in the affected area, swelling, fever, fatigue
Treatments: antibiotics (oral or intravenous), surgery (for severe cases or to remove dead tissue)

Description: Osteoporosis is a bone disease that occurs when the body loses too much bone, makes too little bone, or both. As a result, bones become weak and may break from a fall or, in serious cases, from sneezing or minor bumps.
Symptoms: back pain, loss of height over time, a stooped posture, a bone that breaks much more easily than expected
Treatments: calcium and vitamin d supplements, medications such as bisphosphonates, hormone therapy, and denosumab, regular weight-bearing and muscle-strengthening exercise, fall prevention measures, such as removing hazards and improving lighting in the home

Description: Otitis media is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear, which is the space behind the eardrum that contains the small bones that vibrate in response to sound.
Symptoms: ear pain, fever, drainage from the ear, difficulty hearing, irritability
Treatments: watchful waiting, antibiotics, pain relievers, surgery

Description: Ovarian cancer is a cancer that forms in the ovaries. It is the fifth most common cancer among women.
Symptoms: abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, difficulty eating or feeling full quickly, urinary symptoms, back pain, fatigue, indigestion, menstrual irregularities
Treatments: surgery, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Description: Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that typically results in enlarged and deformed bones. It can affect any bone in the body, but most commonly affects the pelvis, spine, skull, and legs.
Symptoms: bone pain, joint pain, headaches, hearing loss, numbness or tingling, enlarged bones, bone deformities
Treatments: bisphosphonate medications, calcitonin, surgery

Description: Pancreatic cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the cells of the pancreas. It can spread quickly and is often difficult to detect early. Pancreatic cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer death in the United States.
Symptoms: abdominal pain, loss of appetite, weight loss, jaundice, nausea, vomiting, new-onset diabetes, fatigue, depression
Treatments: surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Description: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is when blood suddenly bursts into brain tissue, causing damage to your brain. Symptoms usually appear suddenly during ICH. They include headache, weakness, confusion, and paralysis, particularly on one side of your body.
Symptoms: vomiting,  headache,  weakness of one body side,  altered sensorium
Treatments: massage, eat healthy, exercise, consult doctor

Description: Paratyphoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella Paratyphi bacteria. It is usually contracted by consuming contaminated food or water.
Symptoms: fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting
Treatments: antibiotics, fluid and electrolyte replacement, rest and adequate nutrition

Description: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement. It occurs when the brain cells that produce dopamine, a chemical that coordinates movement, die or become impaired. As a result, people with Parkinson's disease may experience tremors, stiffness, slow movement, and difficulty with balance and coordination.
Symptoms: tremors or shaking, usually in the hands, arms, or legs, stiffness or rigidity of the limbs and trunk, slow movement (bradykinesia), impaired balance and coordination
Treatments: medications that increase dopamine in the brain, such as levodopa, dopamine agonists, and mao-b inhibitors, deep brain stimulation (dbs), a surgical procedure that involves implanting electrodes in the brain, physical therapy to improve movement and balance, speech therapy to improve voice and communication, occupational therapy to improve daily activities

Description: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is one of the most common causes of vertigo â€” the sudden sensation that you're spinning or that the inside of your head is spinning. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo causes brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness.
Symptoms: vomiting,  headache,  nausea,  spinning movements,  loss of balance,  unsteadiness
Treatments: lie down, avoid sudden change in body, avoid abrupt head movment, relax

Description: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a break in the inner lining of the stomach, the first part of the small intestine, or sometimes the lower esophagus. An ulcer in the stomach is called a gastric ulcer, while one in the first part of the intestines is a duodenal ulcer.
Symptoms: vomiting,  loss of appetite,  abdominal pain,  passage of gases,  internal itching
Treatments: avoid fatty spicy food, consume probiotic food, eliminate milk, limit alcohol

Description: Peptic ulcer disease is a condition in which painful sores or ulcers develop in the lining of the stomach, small intestine, or esophagus.
Symptoms: abdominal pain or discomfort, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, bloating, belching, weight loss
Treatments: antibiotics to kill h. pylori bacteria, proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid, antacids to neutralize stomach acid, h2 blockers to reduce acid production, lifestyle changes (e.g., avoiding alcohol and spicy foods)

Description: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a condition where there is a narrowing of the arteries that supply blood to the legs and feet.
Symptoms: leg pain, numbness or weakness in legs, coldness in lower leg or foot, "sores on toes, feet or legs that wont heal", change in color of legs
Treatments: smoking cessation, exercise and physical therapy, medications to manage symptoms and prevent blood clots, angioplasty or stenting to open up blocked arteries, surgery to bypass blocked arteries

Description: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a common circulatory problem in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to your limbs.
Symptoms: painful cramping in hip, thigh or calf muscles after certain activities, such as walking or climbing stairs, leg numbness or weakness, coldness in your lower leg or foot, especially when compared with the other side, "sores on your toes, feet or legs that wont heal", a change in the color of your legs, hair loss or slower hair growth on your feet and legs, slower growth of toenails, shiny skin on your legs, no pulse or a weak pulse in your legs or feet, erectile dysfunction, especially in men with diabetes
Treatments: lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, smoking cessation, and healthy diet, medications like blood thinners, cholesterol-lowering drugs, and medications to control blood pressure, angioplasty and stenting, bypass surgery, amputation of the affected limb, in severe cases

Description: Peripheral neuropathy is a condition that occurs when the nerves that carry information to and from the brain and spinal cord to the rest of the body are damaged or diseased.
Symptoms: tingling, burning or prickling sensations in the affected area, sharp, stabbing or shooting pain, extreme sensitivity to touch, lack of coordination and falling, muscle weakness or paralysis if motor nerves are affected, partial or complete loss of sensation if sensory nerves are affected, bowel or bladder dysfunction if autonomic nerves are affected, changes in blood pressure and sweating
Treatments: treatment of the underlying condition that caused the neuropathy, medications to relieve pain, such as over-the-counter painkillers, anti-seizure drugs, and antidepressants, topical treatments like capsaicin cream or lidocaine patches, physical therapy to help maintain strength and balance, occupational therapy to help with everyday activities, surgery, in severe cases

Description: Pertussis, also known as whooping cough, is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis. It can affect people of all ages, but is most dangerous for infants.
Symptoms: cough (often severe and persistent), whooping sound during coughing fits, vomiting, fatigue
Treatments: antibiotics (to prevent the spread of the infection), supportive care (e.g. fluids, rest, and nutrition), vaccination (to prevent infection)

Description: Peyronie's disease is a condition in which fibrous scar tissue develops inside the penis, causing curved, painful erections.
Symptoms: bent penis during an erection, erectile dysfunction, pain during an erection, shortening of the penis
Treatments: medications like collagenase clostridium histolyticum to break down the scar tissue, injections of verapamil or interferon to reduce the size of the plaque, surgery, such as plication or grafting, to straighten the penis, penile implants, in severe cases

Description: Pneumococcal disease is an infection caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae bacteria. It can lead to pneumonia, meningitis, and other infections.
Symptoms: fever, cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, stiff neck, headache
Treatments: antibiotics, vaccination

Description: Pneumonia is an infection in one or both lungs. Bacteria, viruses, and fungi cause it. The infection causes inflammation in the air sacs in your lungs, which are called alveoli. The alveoli fill with fluid or pus, making it difficult to breathe.
Symptoms: cough (with phlegm or without), fever, chills, shortness of breath, rapid breathing, chest pain, fatigue, muscle aches, nausea or vomiting
Treatments: antibiotics to fight the underlying infection, fever reducers (e.g., acetaminophen) to relieve symptoms, cough medicine to reduce coughing, oxygen therapy to help with breathing, fluids and rest

Description: Poliomyelitis, also known as polio, is a highly contagious viral infection that can lead to paralysis, breathing problems, and even death.
Symptoms: fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, stiffness in the neck, muscle weakness or paralysis
Treatments: supportive care, vaccination

Description: Polycystic kidney disease is an inherited disorder in which clusters of cysts develop within the kidneys, eventually causing kidney failure.
Symptoms: pain in the back or side, blood in urine, frequent urination, kidney stones, high blood pressure, abdominal swelling, fatigue, joint pain
Treatments: blood pressure medications to control high blood pressure, antibiotics to treat infections, surgery to remove large cysts or to transplant a new kidney, dialysis to remove waste from the blood if kidneys fail

Description: Polycystic ovary syndrome is a hormonal disorder that causes enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges, leading to infertility and other health problems.
Symptoms: irregular periods, heavy bleeding, acne, excess hair growth, weight gain, fatigue, depression or mood swings
Treatments: birth control pills to regulate periods and decrease androgen levels, anti-androgen medications to reduce excess hair growth and acne, metformin to improve insulin resistance and regulate menstrual cycles, fertility treatments (e.g., in vitro fertilization) for those trying to conceive

Description: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition triggered by a traumatic event such as combat, natural disasters, sexual assault or serious accidents. People with PTSD often experience flashbacks, nightmares, anxiety, and a feeling of detachment from the world.
Symptoms: flashbacks or reliving the traumatic event, nightmares and sleep disturbances, avoiding reminders of the traumatic event, feeling numb or detached from the world, hyperarousal or being easily startled, negative changes in thinking or mood
Treatments: cognitive-behavioral therapy (cbt), eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (emdr), medications such as antidepressants or anti-anxiety drugs

Description: Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) is a chronic liver disease in which the small bile ducts in the liver are gradually destroyed, leading to a buildup of bile and damage to liver cells. The cause of PBC is unknown, but it is thought to be an autoimmune disorder.
Symptoms: fatigue, itching, dry eyes and mouth, enlarged liver or spleen, jaundice, osteoporosis
Treatments: ursodeoxycholic acid (udca) to slow the progression of the disease, vitamin and mineral supplements, medications to relieve itching or other symptoms, liver transplant in severe cases

Description: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic liver disease characterized by inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. Over time, this can lead to liver damage and cirrhosis.
Symptoms: abdominal pain, fatigue, itching, jaundice, weight loss
Treatments: ursodeoxycholic acid, endoscopic therapy, liver transplantation

Description: Prostate cancer is a type of cancer that develops in the prostate, a gland in the male reproductive system. It usually grows slowly and initially remains confined to the prostate gland, where it may not cause serious harm. However, in some cases, it can spread to other parts of the body and become more aggressive.
Symptoms: frequent urination, especially at night, difficulty starting or stopping urination, weak or interrupted urine flow, blood in urine or semen, painful or burning urination, painful ejaculation, difficulty getting or maintaining an erection
Treatments: watchful waiting, surgery, radiation therapy, cryotherapy, hormone therapy, chemotherapy

Description: Psoriasis is a common skin disorder that forms thick, red, bumpy patches covered with silvery scales. They can pop up anywhere, but most appear on the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back. Psoriasis can't be passed from person to person. It does sometimes happen in members of the same family.
Symptoms: red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales, dry, cracked skin that may bleed, itching or burning sensations
Treatments: topical creams and ointments, light therapy, oral medications

Description: Pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs. The blockage is usually caused by a blood clot that travels to the lungs from another part of the body, most commonly the legs.
Symptoms: sudden shortness of breath, chest pain that gets worse with deep breathing or coughing, coughing up blood
Treatments: blood thinners, clot-dissolving medications, surgery

Description: Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) is a condition where there is scarring or thickening of the tissue in the lungs, making it difficult for oxygen to pass through.
Symptoms: shortness of breath, dry cough, fatigue, unexplained weight loss, muscle and joint pain
Treatments: medications to reduce inflammation, oxygen therapy to increase oxygen levels, pulmonary rehabilitation to improve lung function, lung transplant in severe cases

Description: Q fever is a bacterial infection caused by Coxiella burnetii. It can cause fever, headaches, muscle aches, and pneumonia.
Symptoms: fever, headache, muscle aches, chills, sweats, cough, chest pain
Treatments: antibiotics, supportive care

Description: Rabies is a deadly viral infection that is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected animal, such as a dog or bat.
Symptoms: fever, headache, muscle weakness, seizures, excessive salivation, paralysis
Treatments: post-exposure prophylaxis, vaccination

Description: Raynaud's disease is a condition that affects the blood vessels in the fingers and toes, causing them to narrow and reduce blood flow. This can lead to numbness, tingling, and color changes in the affected areas.
Symptoms: numbness, tingling, color changes in fingers and toes, cold fingers and toes
Treatments: avoiding triggers such as cold temperatures and stress, medications to improve blood flow, biofeedback

Description: Rectal cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the rectum, which is the last section of the large intestine.
Symptoms: bleeding from the rectum, changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain or discomfort, weakness and fatigue, unintended weight loss
Treatments: surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Description: Renal failure is a condition where the kidneys are no longer able to filter waste products from the blood.
Symptoms: swelling in hands, feet, and ankles, fatigue, nausea, decreased appetite, shortness of breath
Treatments: dialysis to filter blood, kidney transplant, medications to control underlying causes, dietary changes to manage electrolyte and fluid levels

Description: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection is a common respiratory infection that can cause serious illness, particularly in young children and older adults.
Symptoms: runny or stuffy nose, cough, fever, wheezing, difficulty breathing
Treatments: supportive care, antiviral medication

Description: Restless legs syndrome is a condition that causes an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, often accompanied by uncomfortable sensations in the legs such as tingling, itching, or crawling.
Symptoms: uncontrollable urge to move legs, tingling or crawling sensations in legs, difficulty sleeping
Treatments: medications such as dopamine agonists and opioids, lifestyle changes such as regular exercise and good sleep habits

Description: Rheumatic fever is a complication of untreated strep throat. It can cause inflammation of the heart, joints, and other organs.
Symptoms: fever, joint pain and swelling, chest pain, shortness of breath
Treatments: antibiotics, anti-inflammatory medication, bed rest

Description: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder that causes the body's immune system to attack the joints. This leads to inflammation and damage to the joints, which can cause pain, stiffness, and swelling.
Symptoms: joint pain and stiffness, swelling and tenderness in the joints, fatigue
Treatments: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (dmards), biologic agents

Description: Rift Valley fever is a viral disease that affects both humans and animals. It is most commonly found in sub-Saharan Africa.
Symptoms: fever, headache, muscle pain, fatigue
Treatments: symptomatic treatment, fluid and electrolyte replacement, supportive care

Description: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a bacterial infection that is spread by ticks. It is most commonly found in North and South America.
Symptoms: fever, headache, muscle pain, rash
Treatments: antibiotics, symptomatic treatment, supportive care

Description: Rosacea is a chronic skin condition that causes redness, flushing, and sometimes small, red, pus-filled bumps on the face. It most commonly affects the nose, cheeks, forehead, and chin.
Symptoms: redness on the cheeks, nose, chin or forehead, small visible blood vessels on the face, bumps or pimples on the face
Treatments: topical creams and gels, oral antibiotics, laser therapy

Description: Rotavirus infection is a common cause of diarrhea in infants and young children. It can lead to dehydration and other complications.
Symptoms: diarrhea, vomiting, fever, abdominal pain
Treatments: rehydration therapy, symptomatic treatment, prevention through vaccination

Description: Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection that can cause rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
Symptoms: rash, fever, headache, swollen lymph nodes
Treatments: symptomatic treatment, prevention through vaccination

Description: Salmonellosis is a bacterial infection that can cause diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps. Most people recover without treatment, but in some cases, it can lead to more severe illness.
Symptoms: nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, diarrhea, headache
Treatments: drinking fluids to prevent dehydration, antibiotics (in severe cases)

Description: Sarcoidosis is a disease that causes inflammation in different parts of the body, most commonly the lungs, lymph nodes, skin, and eyes. The inflammation can cause damage to these organs and may cause symptoms such as coughing, shortness of breath, and skin rashes.
Symptoms: shortness of breath, coughing, skin rashes or lesions
Treatments: corticosteroids, immunosuppressive medications, biologic agents

Description: SARS is a serious respiratory illness caused by the SARS coronavirus. It first appeared in Asia in 2003 and spread to several other countries. SARS can cause severe breathing problems, fever, and other symptoms.
Symptoms: fever, chills, dry cough, shortness of breath, muscle aches, headache, sore throat, malaise
Treatments: antiviral medications (in some cases), corticosteroids (to reduce inflammation), oxygen therapy

Description: Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin. It causes intense itching and a rash.
Symptoms: intense itching (especially at night), rash (usually on the hands, feet, or genitals), small, raised bumps on the skin
Treatments: prescription medications to kill the mites, topical creams or lotions

Description: Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection that can cause a bright red rash, fever, sore throat, and other symptoms. It is most common in children between the ages of 5 and 15.
Symptoms: fever, sore throat, bright red rash (usually on the chest, stomach, and limbs), reddening of the tongue (known as "strawberry tongue"), headache, nausea, vomiting
Treatments: antibiotics, over-the-counter pain relievers (to reduce fever and discomfort)

Description: Sciatica is a type of pain that affects the sciatic nerve, which runs from the lower back down to the legs and feet.
Symptoms: pain in the lower back, buttocks, and legs, numbness or tingling in the legs or feet, weakness in the legs, difficulty walking
Treatments: physical therapy, pain medication, steroid injections, surgery

Description: Scleroderma is a group of rare autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and thicken. In some cases, scleroderma can also affect the internal organs such as the lungs, heart, and kidneys.
Symptoms: thickening and hardening of skin, digestive problems, joint pain and stiffness, shortness of breath
Treatments: immunosuppressive medications, medications to treat specific symptoms, physical therapy

Description: Scoliosis is a medical condition where the spine curves sideways. This can cause uneven shoulders, hips, or waist and can sometimes lead to discomfort or difficulty breathing.
Symptoms: uneven shoulders, uneven hips, uneven waist, back pain, difficulty breathing
Treatments: bracing, physical therapy, surgery

Description: Shigellosis is an infection caused by the Shigella bacteria. It can cause diarrhea, fever, and stomach cramps. In severe cases, it can lead to dehydration and other complications.
Symptoms: diarrhea (which may be bloody), fever, stomach cramps, nausea, vomiting
Treatments: drinking fluids to prevent dehydration, antibiotics (in severe cases)

Description: Sickle cell disease is a genetic blood disorder that causes red blood cells to become misshapen and break down more easily than normal, leading to anemia and other complications.
Symptoms: anemia, episodes of pain, jaundice, swelling of hands and feet
Treatments: pain medications, hydroxyurea to reduce the frequency of painful episodes, blood transfusions

Description: Sinusitis is an inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses, which can cause symptoms such as facial pain, pressure, or congestion.
Symptoms: facial pain, pressure in the face, congestion, nasal discharge, cough, headache
Treatments: nasal decongestants, saline nasal irrigation, antibiotics, steroid nasal sprays

Description: Skin cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the skin.
Symptoms: changes in the appearance of moles or other skin lesions, a new growth on the skin, "a sore that doesnt heal", pain, itching, or bleeding on the skin
Treatments: surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy

Description: Sleep apnea is a sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or shallow breaths during sleep. The condition can lead to poor sleep quality and excessive daytime sleepiness.
Symptoms: loud snoring, episodes of breathing cessation during sleep witnessed by another person, gasping or choking during sleep, excessive daytime sleepiness, difficulty concentrating, morning headaches, irritability
Treatments: continuous positive airway pressure (cpap) therapy, oral appliances, surgery, lifestyle changes (e.g. weight loss, quitting smoking, avoiding alcohol and sedatives)

Description: Smallpox is a contagious disease caused by the variola virus. It is characterized by a fever and a distinctive rash.
Symptoms: fever, fatigue, headache, backache, rash
Treatments: vaccination, antiviral drugs, symptomatic relief

Description: Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spaces within the spine, which can put pressure on the nerves that travel through the spine.
Symptoms: pain or numbness in the legs or arms, weakness in the legs or arms, difficulty walking or maintaining balance, loss of bowel or bladder control
Treatments: physical therapy, pain medication, steroid injections, surgery

Description: Spondylitis is a type of arthritis that affects the spine and can cause stiffness, pain, and reduced mobility.
Symptoms: stiffness in the back or neck, pain in the back or neck, reduced mobility, fatigue, loss of appetite
Treatments: exercise, medications, surgery

Description: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is a rare skin condition caused by the bacteria Staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by redness and blistering of the skin.
Symptoms: fever, redness of the skin, blisters on the skin, skin peeling
Treatments: antibiotics, pain relief medication, intravenous fluids

Description: Stomach cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the stomach.
Symptoms: abdominal pain or discomfort, nausea or vomiting, loss of appetite, unintended weight loss, feeling full after eating small amounts of food
Treatments: surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Description: Strep throat is a bacterial infection that affects the throat and tonsils. It is characterized by a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
Symptoms: sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, difficulty swallowing
Treatments: antibiotics, pain relief medication, rest and fluids

Description: A stroke occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted or reduced, which can cause brain cells to die. This can result in various symptoms, depending on which part of the brain is affected.
Symptoms: sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body, sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding speech, sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes, sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination, sudden severe headache with no known cause
Treatments: clot-busting drugs, aspirin or other antiplatelet drugs, anticoagulants, surgery

Description: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Treponema pallidum. It is characterized by a sore or ulcer at the site of infection and a rash that can appear on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
Symptoms: painless sore or ulcer, rash on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, fever, fatigue
Treatments: antibiotics, penicillin injections, regular testing

Description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.
Symptoms: fatigue, fever, joint pain, skin rashes, chest pain, shortness of breath, headaches, confusion, memory loss
Treatments: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids), antimalarial drugs, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologics

Description: Tendinitis is a condition in which the tendons â€” the thick cords that attach muscles to bone â€” become inflamed or irritated.
Symptoms: pain, tenderness, stiffness, swelling, weakness
Treatments: rest, ice, compression, elevation, physical therapy, medications, surgery

Description: Testicular cancer occurs when abnormal cells in the testicles grow and divide uncontrollably, forming a mass or tumor.
Symptoms: a painless lump or swelling in the testicle, a feeling of heaviness in the scrotum, a dull ache in the abdomen or groin
Treatments: surgery to remove the affected testicle (orchiectomy), radiation therapy, chemotherapy

Description: Tetanus is a bacterial infection that affects the nervous system. It is characterized by muscle stiffness and spasms, particularly in the jaw muscles.
Symptoms: muscle stiffness and spasms, jaw cramping, fever, sweating
Treatments: antitoxin medication, muscle relaxants, pain relief medication

Description: Thyroid cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cells of the thyroid gland, which is located in the front of the neck.
Symptoms: a lump or swelling in the neck, pain in the neck or throat, difficulty swallowing or breathing
Treatments: surgery to remove all or part of the thyroid gland, radiation therapy, chemotherapy

Description: Thyroid disease is a common problem that can cause symptoms due to over- or under-function of the thyroid gland.
Symptoms: fatigue, weight changes, muscle weakness, hair loss, depression, difficulty sleeping, rapid heartbeat
Treatments: thyroid hormone replacement therapy, anti-thyroid medications, radioactive iodine, surgery

Description: Tinnitus is a condition where a person hears a ringing, buzzing, or other noise in one or both ears that is not caused by an external sound.
Symptoms: ringing, buzzing, or other noise in the ears, difficulty sleeping or concentrating, anxiety or depression
Treatments: identifying and treating underlying causes (e.g., earwax buildup, high blood pressure), using a white noise machine or other sound therapy, counseling or therapy to help manage anxiety or depression

Description: Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by the Toxoplasma gondii parasite. It is usually transmitted through contact with contaminated cat feces, eating undercooked meat, or vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy.
Symptoms: flu-like symptoms (such as fever, fatigue, body aches), swollen lymph nodes, muscle aches and pains, headache, sore throat, skin rash, inflammation of the lungs, heart, or eyes (in severe cases)
Treatments: antibiotics (such as sulfadiazine, pyrimethamine, and clindamycin), corticosteroids (to reduce inflammation in severe cases), symptomatic treatment (such as pain relievers, fever reducers, and rest)

Description: Trachoma is a bacterial infection of the eyes caused by the Chlamydia trachomatis bacterium. It is usually transmitted through contact with contaminated hands, clothing, or flies.
Symptoms: irritation and redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, discharge from the eyes, sensitivity to light, blurred vision, formation of small bumps on the inner surface of the eyelids (in severe cases)
Treatments: antibiotics (such as azithromycin and tetracycline), surgery (in severe cases), facial cleanliness and environmental improvements (to prevent transmission)

Description: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease usually caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) bacteria. Tuberculosis generally affects the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. Most infections show no symptoms, in which case it is known as latent tuberculosis.
Symptoms: coughing (with or without blood), chest pain, fatigue, fever, night sweats, loss of appetite, weight loss, shortness of breath (in severe cases)
Treatments: antibiotics (such as isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol), directly observed therapy (dot) to ensure compliance with medication, surgery (in severe cases), vaccination (in some cases)

Description: Tularemia is a rare infectious disease caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis.
Symptoms: fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, progressive weakness
Treatments: antibiotics, supportive care

Description: An acute illness characterized by fever caused by infection with the bacterium Salmonella typhi. Typhoid fever has an insidious onset, with fever, headache, constipation, malaise, chills, and muscle pain. Diarrhea is uncommon, and vomiting is not usually severe.
Symptoms: chills,  vomiting,  fatigue,  high fever,  nausea,  constipation,  abdominal pain,  diarrhoea,  toxic look (typhos),  belly pain
Treatments: eat high calorie vegitables, antiboitic therapy, consult doctor, medication

Description: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi.
Symptoms: fever, headache, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, fatigue, diarrhea or constipation, rash
Treatments: antibiotics, supportive care

Description: Typhus is a group of infectious diseases caused by bacteria called Rickettsia.
Symptoms: fever, headache, muscle pain, nausea and vomiting, rash, cough
Treatments: antibiotics, supportive care

Description: Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation and sores (ulcers) in the lining of the large intestine.
Symptoms: abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, urgency to defecate, weight loss, fatigue
Treatments: anti-inflammatory medications, immunosuppressive medications, biologic therapy, surgery

Description: Urinary tract infection: An infection of the kidney, ureter, bladder, or urethra. Abbreviated UTI. Not everyone with a UTI has symptoms, but common symptoms include a frequent urge to urinate and pain or burning when urinating.
Symptoms: burning micturition,  bladder discomfort,  foul smell of urine,  continuous feel of urine
Treatments: drink plenty of water, increase vitamin c intake, drink cranberry juice, take probiotics

Description: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of the urinary system, including the kidneys, bladder, and urethra.
Symptoms: burning sensation during urination, frequent urge to urinate, passing small amounts of urine, cloudy urine, strong-smelling urine, pelvic pain
Treatments: antibiotics, pain relievers

Description: Uterine cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cells of the uterus (womb), which is a hollow organ in the female reproductive system.
Symptoms: abnormal vaginal bleeding (e.g., bleeding between periods, after menopause), pelvic pain or pressure, pain during sex
Treatments: surgery to remove the uterus (hysterectomy) andor other affected organs, radiation therapy, chemotherapy

Description: Varicella, commonly known as chickenpox, is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
Symptoms: fever, headache, tiredness, rash, itching
Treatments: antiviral medications, calamine lotion, acetaminophen (tylenol) for fever and discomfort

Description: A vein that has enlarged and twisted, often appearing as a bulging, blue blood vessel that is clearly visible through the skin. Varicose veins are most common in older adults, particularly women, and occur especially on the legs.
Symptoms: swelling, aching pain, heaviness, burning or itching, discoloration, ulcers
Treatments: compression stockings, sclerotherapy, laser treatment, endovenous ablation therapy, surgery

Description: Venous insufficiency is a condition where the veins in the legs are unable to pump blood back up to the heart effectively, leading to swelling, pain, and other symptoms.
Symptoms: swelling in the legs, ankles, or feet, pain, aching, or cramping in the legs, skin changes (e.g., discoloration, thickening, ulcers)
Treatments: wearing compression stockings, elevating the legs when sitting or lying down, medications to improve blood flow or prevent blood clots

Description: Vertigo is a sensation of spinning dizziness that can occur without any movement. It is often caused by problems with the inner ear or brain.
Symptoms: dizziness, balance problems, nausea or vomiting, headache, sweating, ringing in the ears
Treatments: medications to relieve symptoms, vestibular rehabilitation therapy, surgery (in severe cases)

Description: Vibrio infection is a bacterial infection caused by the Vibrio bacterium.
Symptoms: diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, fever, chills, low blood pressure
Treatments: antibiotics, supportive care

Description: Vitiligo is a condition that causes the skin to lose its pigment, resulting in white patches on the skin. It occurs when the cells that produce pigment in the skin are destroyed.
Symptoms: white patches on the skin, premature whitening of hair on scalp, eyelashes, eyebrows or beard, loss of color inside the mouth, loss or change in color of the retina
Treatments: topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors, narrowband ultraviolet b (nb-uvb) therapy, excimer laser, depigmentation (in severe cases)

Description: West Nile virus (WNV) is a viral infection that typically spreads through the bite of an infected mosquito. Most people with WNV do not experience any symptoms. However, about 1 in 5 people who are infected will develop a fever along with other symptoms.
Symptoms: fever, headache, body aches, fatigue, back pain, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes
Treatments: there is no specific treatment for wnv infection, over-the-counter pain relievers can help reduce fever and relieve some symptoms, in severe cases, hospitalization may be necessary for supportive care, such as intravenous fluids, pain management, and nursing care

Description: Whiplash is a neck injury that occurs when the head is suddenly jerked backward and then forward, causing damage to the soft tissues in the neck.
Symptoms: neck pain and stiffness, headache, shoulder pain, dizziness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating
Treatments: pain medication, physical therapy, chiropractic care, muscle relaxants, corticosteroid injections, surgery (in rare cases)

Description: Wilson's disease is a rare genetic disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain and other organs. This can lead to liver disease, neurological problems and psychiatric symptoms.
Symptoms: fatigue, abdominal pain, jaundice, tremors, difficulty speaking or swallowing, psychiatric symptoms (e.g. depression, anxiety, psychosis)
Treatments: chelation therapy, zinc therapy, liver transplant (in severe cases)

Description: A yeast infection is a common fungal infection caused by the overgrowth of the Candida fungus.
Symptoms: vaginal itching, burning sensation during urination, pain during sexual intercourse, swelling and redness of the vulva, white, thick, odorless vaginal discharge with a cottage cheese-like appearance
Treatments: antifungal creams, ointments, or suppositories, antifungal oral medications, boric acid suppositories, probiotics

Description: Zika virus is a mosquito-borne virus that can cause mild to severe symptoms, including fever, rash, joint pain, and red eyes. It can also cause birth defects in infants born to infected mothers.
Symptoms: fever, rash, joint pain, red eyes (conjunctivitis), muscle pain, headache
Treatments: rest, fluids, pain relievers, avoiding mosquito bites, pregnant women should avoid travel to areas with ongoing zika virus outbreaks
